title: Voting guide: Here’s what voters need to know before Boston’s Tuesday election
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Boston polls will be open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. across 275 precincts for Tuesday's municipal election.
Mayor Michelle Wu is running unopposed, while Boston City Council has contested races for four at-large seats.
Ballots are available in multiple languages, and 32,737 mail-in ballots have been returned out of 51,769 distributed.

title: The Bruins’ second line is looking like a difference-maker, in more ways than one
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The Bruins' second line of Mittelstadt, Zacha, and Arvidsson are driving offense, outscoring opponents 4-2 in recent games.
Mason Lohrei, scratched three games in a row, aims to learn from sidelines as head coach Marco Sturm encourages his improvement.
Coach Marco Sturm credits Mittelstadt's performance post-benching, with the Bruins winning four of their last five games.

title: Garrett Crochet, Roman Anthony named finalist for Cy Young, Rookie of the Year Awards
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Garrett Crochet of the Boston Red Sox is a finalist for the AL Cy Young Award after leading with 205.1 innings and 255 strikeouts.
Crochet posted an 18-5 record with a 2.59 ERA, excelling in his first season and outperforming in a lone postseason outing against the Yankees.
Red Sox's Roman Anthony is a finalist for the AL Rookie of the Year, slashing .292/.396/.463 with eight home runs in 71 games.

title: Ranking top priorities for Patriots at NFL trade deadline
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The New England Patriots are considering acquiring an edge rusher like Arden Key or Hendrickson before the trade deadline.
Patriots need to address running back depth, potentially targeting Cleveland's Jerome Ford due to injuries in their current roster.
The team is evaluating options for cornerback and safety to ensure depth, particularly versatile players for secondary coverage.

title: Patriots’ pass-protection issues are mounting as Drake Maye ties worrisome stat from last year
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: The New England Patriots have allowed 34 sacks this season, the second-most in the NFL.
Drake Maye is taking heavy hits, with 12 sacks in the last two games alone, affecting team performance.
Offensive line and quarterback must improve; both rookies and strategy flaws contribute to protection issues.

title: Downtown Boston hotel settles discrimination complaint after woman was accused of being a man
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Liberty Hotel in Boston settled a discrimination complaint involving a woman accused of being a man in a bathroom.
The settlement requires a $10,000 donation to a nonprofit and updates to the hotel's nondiscrimination policies.
The woman's lawyer plans to file a civil lawsuit against the hotel for punitive damages and further accountability.

title: Falcons coach walks back ‘clapgate’ accusations after Patriots push back
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Falcons coach Raheem Morris retracted accusations of Patriots simulating snap counts in their 24-23 victory.
A key play involved Falcons QB Michael Penix Jr. throwing the ball away leading to an intentional grounding penalty.
Patriots coach Mike Vrabel dismissed the 'clapgate' controversy, citing no intentional deception during the game.

title: Alex Bregman opts out of Red Sox contract, will hit free agency
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Alex Bregman opted out of his Red Sox contract, entering free agency with two years and $80 million left.
Bregman had a .273/.360/.462 batting slash with 18 home runs and 62 RBIs in 114 games for Boston in 2025.
The Red Sox may try to retain Bregman, but teams like the Tigers and Mariners are reportedly interested.

title: Patriots NFL trade deadline live updates: Will New England make moves before Tuesday?
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The New England Patriots are contemplating trades to improve their 7-2 roster before the NFL trade deadline.
Potential trade targets for the Patriots include Miami's Jaylen Waddle and New Orleans' Alvin Kamara.
New England is reportedly shopping OLB Anfernee Jennings while considering acquiring additional pass-rushing talent.

title: After an eventful week, Bruins’ Hampus Lindholm has ‘a lot to be thankful for’
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Hampus Lindholm and fiancée Amanda welcomed their first child, Magnolia, naming her after a meaningful tree.
Lindholm returned to the Bruins' lineup after a lower-body injury, helping the team to a 5-1-0 record.
Bruins coach Marco Sturm credits Lindholm's presence for improving defense, reducing goals per game from 4.25 to 2.3.
